page.title: List of fictional cats and other felines

revisions.rev:
{{Cleanup-list|date=July 2011}} [[File:Offterdinger Der gestiefelte Kater (1).jpg|thumb|right|[[Puss in Boots]] from Charles Perrault's fairytale, here illustrated by [[:de:Carl Offterdinger|Carl Offterdinger]]]] A '''list of fictional [[cat]]s and other [[Felinae|felines]]'''.
==Legends, myths, folklore and fairy tales== * Several cats appear in [[Aesop's Fables]] such as [[The Fox and the Cat (fable)|The Fox and the Cat]]. * [[Bast (goddess)|Bast]] (or Bastet), [[Ancient Egypt|Egyptian]] [[goddess]] with the head of a cat; see also [[Sekhmet]].<ref name=pc/> * [[Belling the cat]] — a fable attributed to Aesop but first recorded in medieval times. * Cats are not mentioned in the [[Biblical canon|canonical Bible]].<ref>{{citation |title=Why Are There No Cats in the Bible? |author=George Davidson |publisher=Arcturus Publishing Ltd |year=2009 |isbn=9781848371958}}</ref> There is a single mention in the apocryphal [[Letter of Jeremiah|Epistle of Jeremiah]], "Now shall ye see in Babylon gods of silver, and of gold, and of wood, borne upon shoulders, which cause the nations to fear. ... Upon their bodies and heads sit bats, swallows, and birds, and the cats also."<ref>{{citation |title=Bible animals |page=36 |author=John George Wood |year=1870 |url=http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=QUYaAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA36 |chapter=The Cat}}</ref> * [[Cait Sidhe]], a [[fairy]] creature from [[Celtic mythology]].<ref name=pc>{{citation |title=Planet Cat |chapter=Legendary Cats |page=12 |isbn=9780618812592 |year=2007}}</ref> * The cats in ''[[A Book of Cats and Creatures]]'' such as ''Katchen the Cat'' and ''Pussy Cat Twinkle'' — fairy-tales compiled by [[Ruth Manning-Sanders]]. * [[Dick Whittington and His Cat|Dick Whittington's cat]] * [[Freyja]]'s horse-sized winged cats, who draw the [[Norse mythology|Norse]] goddess's chariot * The cat was the animal of [[Libera (mythology)|Libera]], the [[Roman mythology|Roman mythological]] personification of [[Liberty]], because it hates to be constrained * The cat in the adage recalled by [[Lady Macbeth]], which was ''catus amat pisces sed non vult tingere plantas'' — the cat wanted fish but would not wet its feet.<ref>{{citation |url=http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=Ehk9AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA110 |title=Macbeth |publisher=Cambridge University Press |page=110 |year=1952}}</ref> * Mackie Boots, a fictional student-cat from Virginia Military Institute * [[Maneki Neko]], the lucky beckoning cat of [[Japan]] * [[Nekomata]], a Japanese cat-demon with two tails * [[Patripatan]], an Indian cat that went to heaven to pick a flower.<ref name=pc/> * [[Puss in Boots]], a cat from a European folk tale * Ratto (or Raton) in [[La Fontaine]]'s "[[The Monkey and the Cat]]" * [[Sekhmet]], [[Ancient Egypt|Egyptian]] [[goddess]] with the head of a lion
==In advertising== * The Fancy Feast cat is played by Dearheart Silver Chinchilla Persians in the USA, Cherie-Finesse Chinchilla Longhairs in Europe, and by the Kaamari Katz Australian Tiffany in Australia. All these originated with the chinchilla Persian as a foundation breed. * The [[Chesapeake and Ohio Railway]] (later the [[Chessie System Railroad]]) used a logo with a sleeping kitten "Chessie" and the slogan "sleep like a kitten and arrive fresh as a daisy on the C&O". Later, Chessie went on to become part of the logo of Chessie System...in what most railroaders and railfans call the "Chess-C". * [[Energizer Holdings|Eveready]], "nine lives" battery logo. * Frank the cat aka the Big Kahuna on [[Whiskas]] cat food commercials * [[Hector the Cat]], a mascot for the teaching of road safety to children in Australia * Rap Cat, a puppet cat featured in several [[Checkers (fast food)|Checkers and Rally's]] fast-food restaurant commercials * Felix from the NestlÃ© Purina/Friskies Felix cat food ads. * [[Chester Cheetah]] is the mascot for [[Frito-Lay]]'s cheese curl chip, [[Cheetos]]. * Baxter, the cat in [[Meow Mix]] commercials. * Hikonyan, a samurai cat mascot at [[Hikone castle]] * Hodori, the official mascot of the 1988 Summer Olympics in Seoul, Korea. * [[Morris the cat|Morris]] the mascot for [[9Lives|9-Lives]] cat food. *[[Tony the Tiger]] is the mascot for [[Kellogg Company|Kellogg]]'s [[Frosted Flakes]] breakfast cereal. *[[Reform Cat]] is a mascot for the [[United Kingdom Alternative Vote referendum, 2011|UK Yes to AV Referendum]] campaign and Electoral Reform.

Lewis's [[The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe]] * Baal, who shows character development in Jo Hawk's ''The Man Who Thought He Was Hitler'' * Baby, Ayla's hand-reared [[Panthera leo spelaea|cave lion]] in the [[Earth's Children]] books * Bagheera, a melanistic black panther from The Jungle Book * Bastet, matriarch of a line of Egyptian cats in the [[Amelia Peabody series]] of mystery novels; followed by Anubis, Horus, Seshat, Sekhmet, and The Great Cat of Re * Behemoth (Begemot, {{lang-ru|ÐÐµÐ³ÐµÐ¼Ð¾Ñ}}), the huge, trolley-riding, Satanic black cat in [[Mikhail Bulgakov]]'s ''[[The Master and Margarita]]''; the name belongs to the biblical [[Behemoth]] * Bendigo Bung-Eye, a one-eyed ginger cat in the [[Dick King-Smith]] book ''Saddlebottom'', who helps Saddlebottom, the improperly marked Wessex Saddleback [[pig]] make his fortune in the Royal [[Wessex]] Rifles * Birdie, cat of forensic anthropologist Temperance Brennan in [[Kathy Reichs]]' novels * Blackberry, [[Judy Bolton]]'s cat, who once deflected a gunman by scratching him * "[[The Black Cat (short story)|The Black Cat]]" named Pluto in [[Edgar Allan Poe]]'s short story, a study of the psychology of guilt and death * Blackjack, a black [[Manx (cat)|Manx]], from [[Matt Ruff]]'s ''[[Fool on the Hill (novel)|Fool on the Hill]]'' * Blackmalkin, Greymalkin, and Nibbins, witches' cats in ''The Midnight Folk'' by [[John Masefield]] * Boald Tib, Issy's pet cat in James Joyce's novel ''[[Finnegans Wake]]'' (028.05) * Boabdil, Haroun's cat in [[Esther M. Friesner]]'s book ''The Wishing Season''. * Boon, a cat from an alternate world in the [[The Pendragon Adventure|Pendragon]] series by [[DJ MacHale]] * Boris, the cat who lives at 28 Barbury Lane, in Armistad Maupin's ''Tales of the City'' series * Broccoli from ''The Broccoli Tapes'' by [[Jan Slepian]] * Buttercup, Primrose Everdeen's cat in [[The Hunger Games]]. ==PokÃ©mon== Cats have been listed as one of "The most overused Pokemon designs", but [[GamesRadar]] stated that some of them "actually vary greatly in actual design",<ref name="cat Pokemon">{{cite web|url=http://www.gamesradar.com/ds/f/the-most-overused-pokemon-designs/a-2010072310344160054/g-2009081411831516068/p-2 |title=The most overused Pokemon designs, Pokemon HeartGold / SoulSilver DS Features |author=Carolyn Gudmundson |publisher=GamesRadar |date=Jul 23, 2010 |accessdate=2010-08-01}}</ref> The following is a list of feline-based creatures featured in ''[[PokÃ©mon]]'': * [[Meowth]], a Normal-type [[PokÃ©mon]] based on a [[domestic cat]] or a [[maneki neko]] * [[Persian (PokÃ©mon)|Persian]], a Normal-type [[PokÃ©mon]] based on a [[domestic cat]] or [[mountain lion]] that evolves from [[Meowth]] * [[Espeon]], a Psychic-type [[PokÃ©mon]] based on a [[nekomata]] * [[Skitty]], a Normal-type [[PokÃ©mon]] based on a [[kitten]] * [[Delcatty]], a Normal-type [[PokÃ©mon]] based on a [[domestic cat]] that evolves from [[Skitty]] * [[Absol]], a Dark-type [[PokÃ©mon]] based on a [[kutabe]] and [[black cat]] * [[Shinx]], an Electric-type [[PokÃ©mon]] based on a [[lion cub]] * [[Luxio]], an Electric-type [[PokÃ©mon]] based on a [[young wildcat]] that evolves from [[Shinx]] * [[Luxray]], an Electric-type [[PokÃ©mon]] based on a [[wildcat]] or [[lion]] that evolves from [[Luxio]] * [[Glameow]], a Normal-type [[PokÃ©mon]] based on a [[domestic cat]] * [[Purugly]], a Normal-type [[PokÃ©mon]] based on a [[domestic cat]] that evolves from [[Glameow]] * [[Purrloin]], a Dark-type [[PokÃ©mon]] based on a [[domestic cat]] * [[Liepard]], a Dark-type [[PokÃ©mon]] based on a [[leopard]] that evolves from [[Purrloin]]
